abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            substantial. Positive lessons suggest that the definition of
            realistic objectives, closely tied to the Government's
            priorities in relation to education reforms, was essential
            for the project success, and, the success of individual
            components is, by and large, due to the sustained commitment
            of the relevant government officials. Moreover, the sound
            analytical preparation, and policy consultations facilitated
            implementation, and achievement of development objectives,
            while the flexibility in the training approach enabled a
            responsive training redefinition, tailored to specific
            needs, as suggested by the successful in-service training
            for teachers, which showed positive effects on the quality
            of education. Negative lessons however, indicate that
            institutional weaknesses were apparent in the drafting of
            the education assessment system, which prevented the
            application by the Ministry of Education (MoE), to include
            this key component for quality improvement (thus postponed
            to the following operation). Furthermore, the lack of
            experience with procurement guidelines, was conducive to
            delays, and, the absence of integrated software, to
            facilitate a proactive project management prevented higher
            project ratings. Unfortunately, no provisions were made in
            project accounting practices, to quantify, and include
            in-kind contributions from MoE, as part of the total
            expenditures by the Government.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Secondary Education Support Project
            will continue to assist the Government in: 1) implementing
            its basic and secondary education reform program aimed at
            achieving improved quality and efficiency; and 2) improving
            access to accommodate the projected increase in upper-basic
            and secondary school enrollments. The project will be
            executed over 5 years by the Ministry of Education and
            Sciences (MES). The first component will help MES to improve
            educational delivery mechanisms by financing the
            implementation of the following quality and efficiency
            measures: 1) strengthening the education performance
            evaluation and assessment system by financing institutional
            support for central and provincial evaluation services; 2)
            promoting more effective teaching and training practices for
            about 26,000 teachers, pedagogic and orientation counselors
            and inspectors at school, provincial and central levels; 3)
            strengthening the central and provincial MES administration
            and planning services to improve the existing information
            and feedback mechanisms between the different
            decision-making levels. The second component will provide
            support for improved access by financing: 1) the
            construction of about 30 upper-basic and 44 secondary
            schools; 2) rehabilitation of upper-basic and secondary
            schools in provinces and areas where these are mostly needed
            and the establishment of preventive school maintenance
            system; and 3) provision of instructional equipment,
            training and technical assistance.
